The word "life" is ultimately derived from the Old English word "lif," which means "animation, vitality, soul." This word is related to several other Old English words, such as "libban," which means "to live," and "lifian," which means "to sustain or nourish."

The Old English word "lif" is derived from the Proto-Germanic word "libiz," which is also the source of the Modern English word "live." This Proto-Germanic word is thought to be related to the Proto-Indo-European root "leip," which means "to stick or adhere."

Over time, the meaning of the word "life" has expanded to include not just the animation or vitality of living beings, but also the condition or quality of being alive.
